content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a king who had twelve beautiful daughters.
Each princess was more lovely than the last, with hair like spun gold, eyes like sapphires, and smiles that could melt the coldest winter’s heart.
The king adored his daughters, but he was also very strict, especially when it came to their bedtime.
Every night, the twelve princesses were sent to their grand chamber, where twelve identical beds stood in a row.
The king would lock the door behind them and post a guard outside to ensure they stayed safely inside until morning.
Yet, every morning, the king would find the princesses’ dancing slippers worn through as if they had danced all night.
The princesses themselves were always pale and tired, but no matter how hard the king tried, he could not discover where they had been or how they had escaped.

The mystery of the worn-out slippers spread far and wide, and soon, the king made a proclamation: any man who could uncover the secret of the princesses’ nightly adventures would be granted the hand of one of them in marriage.
If he failed after three nights, however, he would be put to death.
Many princes and noblemen came from distant lands to try their luck, but none succeeded.
They would sit outside the chamber, listening for any sound, but by morning, their eyes would grow heavy, and they would fall into a deep sleep.
When they awoke, the princesses’ slippers were once again in tatters, and the suitors were sent away in shame—or worse.
Now, in a nearby village, there lived a poor soldier who had been wounded in battle.
He was kind-hearted and clever, though he had little to his name.
One day, as he was resting by the roadside, an old woman approached him.
She had a long, silver braid and eyes that twinkled with wisdom.
“Why do you look so troubled, young man?” she asked. The soldier sighed.
“I have no money, no home, and no future.
I wish I could try my luck at the king’s challenge, but what chance does a humble soldier have?”  The old woman smiled.
“Ah, but you have something the others do not—courage and a good heart.
Take this,” she said, handing him a cloak. “When you wear it, you will become invisible.
But beware: do not drink the wine the princesses will offer you, or you will fall into a deep sleep like the others.”  The soldier thanked the old woman and set off for the palace.
When he arrived, he announced himself to the king and said he wished to try his hand at solving the mystery.
The king, though skeptical, agreed to let him try.
That night, the soldier was led to a small room just outside the princesses’ chamber.
The eldest princess, whose name was Liora, brought him a goblet of wine.
Remembering the old woman’s warning, he pretended to drink but instead poured the wine into a hidden pocket in his cloak.
Then, he lay down on the bed and pretended to fall asleep.
Soon, he heard the soft rustling of silk and the whisper of voices.
Peeking through half-closed eyes, he saw the twelve princesses rise from their beds.
They dressed in their finest gowns and slipped on their dancing slippers.
The eldest princess clapped her hands, and the wall of the chamber shimmered like a mirage before parting to reveal a hidden staircase.
The soldier, invisible beneath his cloak, followed them down the stairs.
At the bottom, he found a magical forest where the trees had leaves of silver and branches that sparkled like diamonds.
The princesses walked through the forest until they came to a great lake.
Waiting there were twelve handsome princes in golden boats.
The soldier quietly climbed into the last boat, and the princes rowed them across the lake to a grand palace on the other side.
Inside, the halls were filled with music and laughter, and the princesses danced with their princes until their slippers were in tatters.
The soldier watched in amazement, careful not to be seen.
At the first light of dawn, the princesses hurried back to their boats.
The soldier followed them, unseen, all the way back to their chamber.
As they undressed and climbed into their beds, he slipped out of the room and returned to his own bed, where he pretended to wake just as the king entered.
“Well?” the king demanded. “Did you discover their secret?”  The soldier bowed. “Your Majesty, I have.
Your daughters have been dancing all night in a magical palace beneath the earth.”  The king was astonished.
“Prove it!”  The soldier described the silver forest, the golden boats, and the grand palace in such detail that the king had no choice but to believe him.
He summoned the princesses, who turned pale when they saw the soldier. “Is this true?” the king asked them.
The eldest princess, Liora, stepped forward. “Yes, Father.
We have been dancing every night, but we did not mean to deceive you.
We were under a spell.”  The king was furious at first, but the soldier spoke up.
“Your Majesty, the princesses are not to blame. They were enchanted by the princes who awaited them.
If you will allow it, I would like to marry the eldest princess, Liora, as your proclamation promised.”  The king, though reluctant, could not go back on his word.
He agreed, and the soldier and Liora were married in a grand ceremony.
The other princesses were freed from their enchantment, and the magical palace beneath the earth vanished forever.
And so, the soldier, who had once been poor and wounded, became a prince, and he and Liora lived happily ever after.
The twelve dancing princesses never wore out their slippers again, and the kingdom rejoiced in their joy.
